description: A fast breakdown of The CRAAP Test: Evaluating Data Sources for builders.

hook.text: Librarians created an acronym for evaluating sources. It's called CRAAP â€” and it's surprisingly effective.

buildup.text: CRAAP stands for Currency, Relevance, Authority, Accuracy, and Purpose â€” five checks for any data source.

discovery.text: Is the data current? Is it relevant to your question? Who published it? Can it be verified? What's the motive?

twist.text: Most viral data claims fail at least two of these five checks. Running CRAAP takes seconds.

climax.text: Teaching CRAAP to students, journalists, and voters would dramatically reduce misinformation's spread.

punchline.text: Five questions. That's all it takes to spot bad data.

quiz.question: What does the 'A' in CRAAP stand for?
options: Authority and Accuracy (both A's represent different criteria)
